abstract: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.
snippet: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival.
lead_paragraph: The European Commission on Wednesday fined Intel a record of about $1.45 billion (1.06 billion euros) for abusing its dominance in the market for computer chips to exclude Advanced Micro Devices, which is Intel’s only serious rival, The New York Times’s James Kanter reported.

headline.main: Intel Fined Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case

abstract: The European Commission said Intel had abused its position of dominance in the microchip markets to exclude its rival Advanced Micro Devices.
snippet: The European Commission said Intel had abused its position of dominance in the microchip markets to exclude its rival Advanced Micro Devices.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  The European Commission fined Intel a record 1.06 billion euros Wednesday for abusing its dominance in the computer chip market, the strongest sign yet that regulators worldwide are serious about opening the technology sector to competition.

headline.main: Europe Fines Intel $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case
headline.print_headline: Europe Fines Intel a Record $1.45 Billion in Antitrust Case

abstract: Intel says it won’t change any of its practices despite a massive antitrust fine imposed by European regulators.
snippet: Intel says it won’t change any of its practices despite a massive antitrust fine imposed by European regulators.
lead_paragraph: Update | 11:52 a.m.  Clarified Intel’s comments around reacting to the European’s Commission’s ruling.

headline.main: Intel’s Strategy Won’t Change Despite Antitrust Charges

abstract: Intel’s chief executive, Paul Otellini, is unamused by a European regulator’s sharp comments about the company’s behavior in the PC market.
snippet: Intel’s chief executive, Paul Otellini, is unamused by a European regulator’s sharp comments about the company’s behavior in the PC market.
lead_paragraph: If Intel and the European Commission have feelings for each other, they’re not of the warm and fuzzy variety.

headline.main: Regulator’s Tone Raises Hackles at Intel

abstract: A $1.4 billion fine against Intel, combined with a tough speech by the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, point to a new day for antitrust enforcement in high-tech markets.
snippet: A $1.4 billion fine against Intel, combined with a tough speech by the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, point to a new day for antitrust enforcement in high-tech markets.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s $1.4 billion fine against Intel on Wednesday, combined with a “fair warning” speech this week by the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, point to a new day for antitrust enforcement in high-technology markets worldwide.

headline.main: High-Tech Antitrust Cases: The Road Ahead
